rest as many of them as they can, particularly the
principal men; and if moderate means will not
cause the persons to disperse they must be driven
away or arrested. Such occasions require the exercise cf great coolness and firmness; force must
not be resorted to until it becomes absolutely necessary, but when necessary must be exercised to the
degree required, and the men must act in such a
manner as to make it apparent that they are determined to do their whole duty, and nothing but their
duty.
Sec. 28. To a riot there must be three or more
persons, and all persons who encourage, promote,
or take part in riots, whether by words, signs or
gestures, or by receiving the badges or insignia of
the rioters, are considered rioters, for in this case
all are principal.","fullrs":{},"find":"2686.jp2","dmaccess":{},"dmimage":{},"dmcreated":"2012-01-18","dmmodified":"2012-01-18","dmoclcno":{},"dmrecord":"2685","restrictionCode":"1","cdmfilesize":"370512","cdmfilesizeformatted":"0.35 MB","cdmprintpdf":"0","cdmhasocr":"1","cdmisnewspaper":"0"}
